Titanic was a commercial juggernaut that earned over $2.2 billion at the worldwide box office, holding the record for the highest-grossing film for over a decade. James Cameron became known as one of Hollywood's most successful and influential directors as a result of the movie's enormous box office success. Additionally, Titanic left a mark on popular culture and the movie business. Its popularity rekindled interest in epic romance themes and helped establish the significance of special effects and digital technologies in contemporary filmmaking. 

Set against the scene of the Titanic cruise liner crashing into an iceberg in 1912, which served as the film's backdrop. The film depicts the heartwarming tale of Jack, a struggling painter, and Ruth, an aristocratic woman, who fall in love and set aside their preconceived notions of the outside world. Ultimately, Jack gives up his chance of survival for Ruth. 

In the past, I was unable to comprehend Jack; I always assumed that he was a romantic lad with liberal ideas who enjoyed leading an unrestrained life. The maxim "To make each day count" appealed to me because I desired adventure and independence. There is no purpose in focusing only on love because life is harsh and not a haven for those looking for pleasure. Thinking back on the entire movie, Jack's words and deeds eventually made it clear to me that he is the one who knows the most about love and life. He was the one who taught Rose how to love and live her life to the fullest. In addition to being Rose's lover, Jack Dawson served as her spiritual supporter. He cared for her until she was grey and helped her recall when she was unable to walk anymore: "There was a man named Jack Dawson, and he saved me in every way that a person can be saved." 

The phrase "I trust you" appears frequently throughout the movie, but it is more than simply a phrase; Rose repeatedly descends to the sea-soaked bottom to save Jack, each time vowing to perish. She makes little sense, doesn't give it any thought, and simply shows that she can be trusted by acting accordingly. The tragedy is a wonderful addendum to love, and the ideal interpretation of love warms everyone's hearts from the inside out rather than making them freeze like the Ocean. 

Titanic's cinematography is exceptional in terms of visual and acoustic effects, utilizing cutting-edge digital technology and special effects to give the audience a realistic sense of being on board the ship. A true epic classic is the scene where Jack and Ruth "fly" over the ship's bow. This sequence was shot partially in a studio and partially using special effects. While the actors' sequences were recorded on green cloth and later composited in post-production, the stunning crimson sunset in the sky was shot on location. In addition, the editing and cinematography are first-rate, and they do a fantastic job of bringing the plot to life. For instance, the design and scenes of the cruise ship were captured using the one shot to the end method. The starting and ending frames of the camera accurately plan and manage the so-called one shot until the end, producing a seamless visual effect. 

Titanic is an amazing movie that demonstrates the bravery and resiliency of people as well as the fragility and emotional strength of the human condition. It is a timeless film that, in addition to being visually spectacular, provokes serious reflection on moral principles and the meaning of life.

Titanic is simply a masterpiece. This movie has it all. A tremendous score, deep emotion emphasized by fantastic performances, and incredibly gripping and high-stakes action. There is really something for everyone here.

Before I continue my praise of the film, I think it has one glaring weakness: the present-day plot. For me, this just did not work all that well. I understand that it was implemented for the main story to have a more emotional impact, but it was not needed. It added almost thirty minutes to the runtime, which could have been used for more character development in the story or to have a more streamlined plot. Not to mention, the acting in this section was lackluster. That might be a hot take, but it was something that I noticed during my watch.

Back to the positives. The score is magnificent here. The minute I finished the film, I had an urge to put on this score to be transported back to the Titanic. That does not happen very often to me.

The performances are great all around. Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet's chemistry was perfect. They played off each other so well and really sold this emphatic and rapid love the two shared. The movie spends a lot of time building their relationship and the payoff at the end is worth every second. Billy Zane was an over-the-top asshole, and even though it was cheesy at times, it worked for me. The other ancillary cast members did well, including Kathy Bates, Frances Fisher and Bill Paxton.

This film is really two movies put into one and both of them work excellently. The first half is a charming and cute love story that spends a lot of time on character development, laying the background for motivations and personalities. While this half may have been my favorite, it is slightly outdone by the second half, which is a gripping and suspenseful survival action story. This section is brutal, showing large scale panic and hysteria while also having some incredibly horrific deaths. The chaos was infectious and very scary to watch. Both halves create a great sense of emotion in the audience and complement each other very well.

Overall, this movie had twenty-five years of hype and critical acclaim to live up to, and I am happy to say it passed expectations. Since leaving the theater, I cannot stop thinking about it.

Analysis:
    Titanic is a movie with romance and history. It is adapted from a real story. All the story starts from Rose's memory in the Titanic. By recalling the scene, it brings the audience back to 1920. Through highly restored scenes from the Titanic, the audiences can experience the life on the Titanic. I think Titanic was popular at that time for three reasons: fancy special effects, the romantic story, and that it was based on a real story. Wallace Hartley was a real violinist who played with his band their last song on the Titanic and in their lives. That is the most unforgettable scene for me: while the boat was sinking, the violinists started to play ‘Nearer, My God, to Thee' on the cabin. They didn't rush to try to get a spot from the rescue boat, instead they chose to play this music to calm down people. Here are two different aspects of why they chose to play this song. Firstly, the song can bring people peace. Secondly, the song mentions the coming death, and it acted like a funeral song because most of the people would die because of lack of rescue boats. Through playing this song, people can realize that death is not the end and God is always watching over his people, and they would be able to meet God and their beloved one. Eventually, the violinists sacrificed their lives for playing music to the people. Titanic is not just a movie but also a society, it shows people from different social statuses experiencing that disaster together. There are heroes and villains. The violinists are heroes. Their music brought the Spirit and peace to the boat, and they even all sacrificed themselves in the end.

Never call your ship unsinkable.  So this is about an elderly woman named Rose (Gloria Stuart).  To a captive audience, she tells the story of her younger days (Kate Winslet) when she fell in love with a young man named Jack (Leonardo DiCaprio).  She comes from money, and he is a poor artist.  How can they make it work when she is already engaged and traveling on a ship that will have the most infamous capsizing of all time?  With Titanic, I feel like there are two distinct camps of people.  There's not a lot of middle ground, and it seems like you either love it or hate it.  Here I am reviewing a movie that came out almost 25 years ago, can you guess which party has my membership?  For me, this is just blockbuster filmmaking at its finest.  It's no secret that this was a passion project for the water-obsessed James Cameron, and it is plain to see how inspired he was when he made this.  He created a world that I love to get lost in, which is a major strength of almost his entire library.  I feel like the majority of Titanic haters enjoy ragging on the fictional romance they added to the real-life tragedy, but I have always found it to be highly compelling.  This is Kate and Leo at the very start of their illustrious careers, and they both knock it out of the park.  The chemistry they share is real, and you always understand how they can end up falling for each other, despite the impracticality of them being together as a couple.  As if the demise of this ocean liner wasn't enough of an obstacle for their relationship to overcome, there is also the true villain in the fiancé, played here by Billy Zane.  For me, he is one of the most entertaining antagonists ever created.  He is always slippery, slimy, and privilege personified, and every single line of dialogue he has somehow manages to make each situation worse.  Some of the CGI has not aged terrifically.  Specifically, I'm talking about the wide sweeping daytime shots of the ship towards the beginning, but those moments are fleeting and ultimately don't taint the rest of the film.  Everything else looks spectacular, and many scenes leave me asking how they filmed it to this very day.  They never forget the proportions, and you always recognize the sheer size of this vessel, even though most modern cruise ships now dwarf the Titanic.  The filmmaking is so tight that every time I watch this, I feel like this might just be the time that the ship will miss the iceberg.  I am forever captivated with my heart in my throat whenever I find the three hours to watch this, and the small details with secondary and non-characters will forever be imprinted in my brain.  Titanic is one of my very favorites with good reason.

There is a trend happening more now than ever where people hate on classic films for the sake of hating because they are classic films and loved by the majority of the public. As I start this "Re-watching and Re-visiting films" series, I will be repeating this many times. I do not quite get people's issue and "beef" (to put it less sophisticated) with Titanic. Is it one of the best movies of all time? Not quite. Is it a really well-done film that stays in our minds years and years after seeing it for the first time and if it is playing on a TV channel, you put it on? Why, yes. I understand the bother with a "pointless" love story plot line for dramatization but what's funny is that it works with the strong performances and magical chemistry between DiCaprio and Winslet. But what I want to focus on in Titanic is the little scenes. There are many scenes where the tears uncontrollably fall down your face. Towards more the last section of the film where the boat officially sunk down, there is a shot from sky above of all the passengers screaming and flapping around the water. Up close, it is suffocating hysteria and from afar, it is just one sound in the middle of the gigantic ocean. People being left to die (as there are themes being shown of the lower class being purposely cast aside and the rich prioritized) and people coming to terms this might be their last breath on earth. Playing with camera angles intensifies a small scene for a viewer and makes that small scene stand out in a 3 hour movie.

Shmaltzy, overly long, ridiculously well crafted and disarmingly heartfelt this movie is just larger than life. I think it's pacing problems are best summed up by the very first scene where Bill Paxton's character essentially does the same gag twice with the exact same reaction from his crewmember. Everything that is done in the present day in this film is essentially useless and definitely provides the most unnecessary though not the only element that makes this movie as grandiose as it is. I was ok with it all, but it made the film seem redundant in a lot of places. Do the present-day scenes add to the film? Yes, but only incidentally, it does put us in the frame of mind of the impending tragedy in a very delicate way and makes for a very meaningful and lovely ending scene but all of that was accomplishable in much less time-consuming ways. After all, the love story is the heart of the film, it would have been perfectly acceptable to keep it to just that. What happens on the Titanic is what really sets this movie apart. At it's core this is a romance and that's what gives the wide appeal of the film but in general terms, this is an absolute masterclass (and I can't stress that enough) in disaster film. I got the feeling that that was what drew James Cameron to the Titanic as a potential film, the slow sinking of such a lavish set piece, the impending and ever nearing doom as the water chases after our heroes as they struggle to survive. It is in the disaster elements (and in the glorious shots of the Titanic before that) that the film is entirely justified in it's longevity. The scale of such a disaster demands a film of such scale and Cameron was certainly the filmmaker, perhaps the only filmmaker, who was truly up to the challenge of giving the Titanic justice. So in terms of destruction, this movie absolutely floored me not even mentioning the staggeringly large scale and lavish set design. The scenes in the engine room particularly gave off a visceral sense of largeness and power that was awesome to behold even on my computer screen and the shots of the Titanic's propellers rearing from the water literally took my breath away. Its like this movie's sets are beefy. That's the word that came to me while watching it, I don't know why but that's what I thought. Of course, no amount of excellent cinematography, special effects, set design, music or sound editing will make a complete film and since we all know the story, a genuine personal touch was necessary for this movie to really excel. Well, I won't call it genuine per se but I will call it just as larger than life than the ship it took place on. I don't think it's a secret to anyone just how melodramatic this movie's nuclear romance between poor artist Jack and unsatisfied rich girl Rose is. I suppose it's also cliché to a point but I didn't really mind (it helped soften the cliches when James Horner's score just leans into the schmaltz with full force) I think the film does a good enough job with building up it's emotional center and it sprinkles in enough universally pitiable scenarios (the musicians, the babies, the families) to make it personally devastating as the long, slow burn of the Titanic's destruction unfolds in all of it's glory. The story didn't really hold any long-lasting meaning, but I don't mind that either, it was just a story aiming to be a crowd pleaser and a white knuckler at the same time, and it succeeded really well at both. I liked the whole "jump together" motif. Cameron's exquisite attention to detail in regards to the sets, costumes and of course the innovative CGI is what makes this film work. Also helping it along is the wonderful Kate Winslet as Rose and Leonardo DiCaprio as Jack.  She and Leo DiCaprio have amazing chemistry together as the fictional couple from different worlds. The way that sci-fi and horror director Cameron turns the Titanic into a monster when it hits the iceberg is something to see - the last fifteen minutes of the sinking is awesome to watch.

What doesn't work? With so many amazing real life stories of the passengers and crew of the famous ship, James Cameron decides not just to ignore them, but create a rather foolish and preposterous tale about a missing diamond and filling out the supporting cast with cliched, silent film type characters (the snooty mother, an odious fiancé, a greedy publicity hungry shipping magnate) which takes away from the natural power of the famous shipwreck. Billy Zane is particularly bad here in a Snidely Whiplash-esque turn here as Rose's fiancé Cal Hockley, complete with an equally nefarious sidekick/right hand man played by David Warner. And Frances Fisher as Rose's mercenary mother Ruth, gives an icy, one-dimensional performance, like a scheming matriarch in a nighttime soap opera. Fisher is a much better actress than that. And Kathy Bates is criminally wasted as Molly Brown, who was probably the ballsiest passenger onboard. Her presence is muted here, but Bates works with what she's got. And the crew and second class passengers are pretty much ignored. We are left with the wealthy, entitled and elitist first class passengers and the naive, plucky and resourceful immigrants in third class. No one else counts. I also like Bill Paxton in his role as the fortune hunter Brock. 

But the film is infectious fun despite its glaring flaws; it's impossible to not get caught up in the sheer spectacle, from the treasure hunters using cutting edge technology to inspect the Titanic's rusty bones, to the excitement of a glamorous ocean liner making its maiden voyage, to the tragically dramatic wreck. The film still manages to impress.
